Fit a Univariate GLM via IRLS

Source: R/utils.R
univariate_irls_glm.Rd

Efficiently fits a univariate generalized linear model (GLM) for a single predictor using iteratively reweighted least squares (IRLS), with a fixed offset and known dispersion parameter. Returns only the slope estimate.

univariate_irls_glm(
  x,
  y,
  family = gaussian(),
  offset = 0,
  dispersion = 1,
  max_iter = 25,
  tol = 1e-08
)

Arguments

x

Numeric vector of predictor values.

y

Numeric vector of response values.

family

A GLM family object (e.g., gaussian(), binomial(), poisson(), etc.). Must inherit from class "family".

offset

Numeric scalar or vector of known offsets (default: 0).

dispersion

Numeric scalar dispersion parameter (default: 1). Used for two-parameter families (Gaussian, Gamma, inverse Gaussian).

max_iter

Integer. Maximum number of IRLS iterations (default: 25).

tol

Numeric. Convergence tolerance on the change in slope (default: 1e-8).

Value

A numeric scalar: the estimated slope coefficient \(\beta\).

Details

This function solves for the slope coefficient \(\beta\) in the model $$\eta = \text{offset} + \beta\,x,\quad \mu = g^{-1}(\eta),$$ where \(g\) is the link function of the specified family. At each IRLS iteration, it constructs the working response $$z = \eta + (y - \mu) / g'(\eta)$$, computes weights $$W = \{g'(\eta)\}^2 / \bigl[\mathrm{Var}(\mu)\times\phi\bigr]$$, and then updates \(\beta\) by weighted least squares: $$\beta \leftarrow \frac{\sum_i W_i\,x_i\,(z_i - \text{offset}_i)} {\sum_i W_i\,x_i^2}.$$ Iteration stops when the absolute change in \(\beta\) is below tol, or when max_iter is reached. If a non‐positive or non‐finite denominator arises, a warning is issued and the current estimate is returned.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Gaussian example
set.seed(0)
x <- rnorm(100)
y <- 3*x + rnorm(100)
univariate_irls_glm(x, y, family = gaussian(), offset = 0)

# Logistic example
x <- rnorm(200)
p <- 1 / (1 + exp(-x))
y <- rbinom(200, 1, p)
univariate_irls_glm(x, y, family = binomial(link = "logit"), offset = 0)

# Poisson example
x <- rnorm(150)
lambda <- exp(1 + 2*x)
y <- rpois(150, lambda)
univariate_irls_glm(x, y, family = poisson(link = "log"), offset = 0)
} # }
